paragraphs.text: Obama and Cameron's 'solutions' for cybersecurity will make the internet worse.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The current state of the US and UK governments' ass-backwards approach to cybersecurity was on full display this week- culminating with British Prime Minister David Cameron and President Obama meeting to discuss the issue at the White House on Friday
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When it comes to cybersecurity
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it seems the UK and US want to embrace every crazy idea except what we know actually works
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The UK's Cameron suggested earlier in the week he wants to outlaw certain forms of encryption
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which could potentially lead to some of the world's most popular messaging apps (like iMessage and WhatsApp) being banned in the UK
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That speech had been ridiculed from all angles for the past few days, with various experts labeling it a nightmare for Internet security- on par with authoritarian regimes such as Russia and China- and economically devastating for the British information technology industry
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Meanwhile, the White House has proposed a huge expansion of penalties under the highly-controversial law that was used to prosecute Reddit co-founder and privacy rights advocate Aaron Swartz
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: passed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the administration's proposal could further criminalize mundane Internet activity - for example, potentially allowing for a ten-year jail sentence for sharing your HBO GO password - all to supposedly target foreign hackers that the law would likely never reach
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Less than 24 hours before Cameron-Obama the meeting
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Guardian published a secret report based on previously unreleased Snowden documents showing that the US government is fully aware that encryption is vital for security, and that the government risked leaving themselves vulnerable if they didn't start implementing it on their own systems quicker
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The British government likely knows this too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: many of their employees use email encryption
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: UK even recommend citizens use encryption to protect their data on a government website
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: At the press conference after the meeting, Obama commendably didn't embrace Cameron's proposal when asked about it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even Cameron seemed to at least appear to back off his own anti-encryption proclamation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: saying he's "not trying to enunciate some new doctrine."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: just because Cameron's been proven to be technically illiterate and may be attempting to publicly back away from his most radical proposal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that doesn't mean that he won't later push forward
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: FBI director Jim Comey proposed similar legislation to Cameron's just a few months ago
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Cameron used eerily similar talking points in Washington on Friday as Comey did in late 2014
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Plus, the rest of Cameron's plan is downright scary for Internet privacy even without a formal encryption ban
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And then there's the White House's so-called solution to the cybersecurity problem, which they unveiled earlier this week
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: President Obama introduced it saying we had to do something about incidents like the headline-grabbing Sony hack, or the juvenile hijacking of US Central Command's twitter account
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what he didn't say was that those proposals wouldn't have stopped those attacks at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Part of the Obama administration's proposal would dramatically expand the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, the oft-abused and notorious statute that the Justice Department used to threaten the late Internet activist Aaron Swartz with 35 years in jail
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: (Aaron later took his own life while awaiting trial
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The CFAA already has incredibly harsh penalties, so much so that there's been a movement for years to reduce them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: how the administration thinks increasing CFAA penalties is going to worry either North Korean hackers or ISIS sympathizers (or more likely pranksters) who take advantage of negligent password practices is anyone's guess
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It would also put countless security researchers at further risk of prosecution, the exact type of people the government should consulting with
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: before making these ill-thought proposals, not driving underground
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: At the same time
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Congress has re-introduced their annual "info-sharing" cybersecurity bill
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which is really just a thinly-veiled way to siphon off more of Americans' private data without court oversight
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As EFF put it, the bill "offered new authorities that could be abused by companies to spy on users, and offered broad legal immunity for disclosing the information obtained with the government
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Sometimes they even granted companies the ability to 'hack back'... a perfect storm threatening our online privacy."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The President's alternative bill is a bit less sweeping, but not by much
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So, Congress and Obama seem to be finally on the same page about something: harsher penalties that won't reach the hackers they were worried about and invasive "info-sharing" that doesn't come close to solving existing problems
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: God forbid there be a full rebirth of the US-UK relationship, or that both sides of the Atlantic seek a full, two-state ban on encryption
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Even full government gridlock would be better than that
paragraphs.label: assumption
